Executive Summary
EPA Risk Management Plan- Resubmit
Schoep's Ice Cream- Madison, WI 53704
Revised 6/8/2014


Description of Facility and Regulated Substance Handled:
Schoep's Ice Cream Company process Ice Cream Products.  The facility utilizes Anhydrous Ammonia as a refrigerant to maintain the proper temperatures of Milk, Cream, and Ice Cream at 514 Division Street Madison, WI 53704.  Ammonia, a gas at normal atmospheric temperature and pressure, is used in an anhydrous form liquefied under pressure in a two stage process.  The refrigeration system consists of a High Pressure Receiver, Evaporators, Compressors, Condensers, Vessels, Piping and numerous types of Valves.
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:  
Schoep's Ice Cream Company is dedicated to promoting safe handling of hazardous materials for the sake of the Plant, Employees and Surrounding Community.  The facility is complying with OSHA's Process Safety Management standard (PSM), Title 29 Code of federal regulations (CFR) 1910.119, and the EPA's Risk Management Program regulations (RMP), Title 40 CFR Part 68.  The purpose of these regulations is to ensure that the refrigeration system is operated and maintained in such a way as to prevent releases of ammonia from the system.  Also, these programs ensure the development of procedures that serve to minimize the impact of releases in the event that they do occur, as well as outlining proper emergency response steps.
Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:
As a part of its desire to promote the safety of its employees and the surrounding community, Schoep's Ice Cream Co. has established numerous programs that serve to prevent accidental releases of ammonia.  Predominate among these programs is process safety management; PSM is organized into 14 elements. (Addressed in the same order as they are presented in the regulatory requirements.)
Element 1-Employee Participation: PSM must involve

tems require review by both operators and a technical manager, and require management authorization prior to implementation.
Specific procedures that are followed to develop and maintain Schoep's   management of change procedures are contained in Element 10, Management of Change.
Element 11 -Incident Investigation:  The purpose of investigating serious incidents and near misses is to understand what happened (or could have happened) and then to prevent any recurrence of similar incidents, thereby improving the safety of the process. A formal incident investigation must be performed any time there is an incident which resulted in, or which could reasonably have resulted in (near miss), a catastrophic release of ammonia. For the purpose of this guideline, a catastrophic release is defined as a major uncontrolled emission, fire, or explosion involving ammonia that presents serious danger to employees, the employees of contractors working on site, or to off-site neighbors. Schoep's approach goes beyond the minimum requirements (because small occurrences can lead to larger ones), and Schoep's wants to learn/improve from our experiences. 
Specific procedures that are followed to develop and maintain Schoep's incident investigation procedures are contained in Element 11, Incident Investigation.
Element 12 -Emergency Planning and Response: Written emergency response plans are required for all ammonia refrigeration facilities.  Facilities must designate at least one plant contact to interface with emergency responders. The emergency planning and response guidelines contain the emergency action plan requirements and the essential steps necessary to initiate, conduct, and terminate an emergency response action. 
Specific procedures that are followed to develop and maintain Schoep's emergency response plans are contained in Element 12, Emergency Planning and Response. These procedures must be consistent with other Emergency Guidelines for a specific facility.

The equipment and system components covered by the MI program are those that contain ammonia, plus those key support or utility systems and equipment, which are considered critical to the safety and reliability of the ammonia system.
Specific procedures that are followed to develop and maintain Schoep's Mechanical Integrity program are contained in Element 8, Mechanical Integrity.
Element 9 - Hot Work Permit: The purpose of the hot work permit procedure is to ensure that employees, contractors and company property are properly protected against fire, explosion, and other dangers resulting from hot work (cutting and welding and any other spark producing operation such as brazing, grinding, burning, and exposure of energized electrical conductors) in or near a process.
Specific procedures that are followed to develop and maintain the Schoep's hot work permit guidelines are contained in Element 9, Hot Work Permit.
Element 10 -Management of Change (MOC): Any facility or process is continually undergoing change. Changes may be implemented to improve the efficiency of the operation, improve the operability, and improve safety or to replace mechanical equipment.  Changes to process chemistry, technology, equipment, procedures, or facilities must be analyzed to ensure that existing safeguards against catastrophic releases are not compromised. The objective of this procedure is to help ensure that changes are properly reviewed and that hazards introduced by the implementation of the change are identified and controlled before the change is implemented. The management of change procedures should be used as the gatekeeper of the PSM program to ensure that as changes are made, the facility's PSM program is modified as needed. Compliance Audits:	 Schoep's will perform an audit of its process safety management program at least once every three years (for regulatory compliance), and more frequently as warranted. Self-auditing is a cost effective, instructive, and positive approach to improving the safety of a process provided that the auditors are impartial to the process and management actively pursues implementation of audit recommendations. It is also a process that ensures continuous improvement is being made in safely operating and managing the Ammonia refrigeration systems at Schoep's facilities. The steps involved in conducting a compliance audit are: ¿ Define the Audit Requirements ¿Prepare for the Audit ¿ Conduct the Audit ¿Report on the Audit Findings ¿ Follow Up on the Audit Findings 
Specific procedures that are followed to develop and maintain Schoep's compliance audit program are contained in Element 13, Compliance Audits.
Element 14 - Trade Secrets: Subject to the rules in the HazCom Standard, employees and their representatives shall have access to trade secret information in PHAs and other documents required by the PSM Standard. The employer may, however, require employees to execute confidentiality agreements providing that trade secrets will not be disclosed.
Schoep's trade secrets policy is defined in Element 14, Trade Secrets.
PSM Standard Maintenance: The Process Safety Management (PSM) program is an evergreen system.  As described above the program has 14 PSM Elements, where each element contains various information in the form of electronic and paper (hard copy) files/documents.  The information in the PSM program must be kept current and accurate to comply with OSHA regulations. 
Facility Management Responsibilities:	Facility management, specifically the President, is ultimately responsible for the safety of the employees, contractors, and the surrounding population.  Implementation of the PSM Standard is designed to reduce the risk to employees, contractors, a

nd the surrounding population.  To ensure proper implementation of the PSM Standard, the Facility Management will assign a PSM Coordinator.
PSM Coordinator Responsibilities: It is the responsibility of the PSM Coordinator to ensure the PSM program is fully implemented and kept current.  The PSM Coordinator will steward the implementation of the 14 PSM Elements and report deficiencies to Facility Management and appropriate personnel.  Typical tasks the PSM Coordinator will perform include: ¿Schedule and coordinate Process Hazard Analysis. ¿Facilitate certification of the Operating Procedures. ¿Ensure training records are maintained for affected and authorized employees. ¿Ensure annual review of ammonia refrigeration contractor qualifications (training and safety records). ¿Ensure pre-startup safety reviews are completed, documented, and filed. ¿Ensure ammonia refrigeration maintenance tests and inspections are performed to standard and documented properly. ¿Facilitate the management of change process and ensure all documentation and training is complete prior to implementation of the change. ¿Coordinate PSM incident investigations and ensure recommendations are implemented in a timely manner. ¿ Coordinate PSM compliance audits and ensure recommendations are implemented in a timely manner.
Schoep's Management Responsibilities: 	Schoep's Management will support the PSM Coordinator and the Facility Management as needed to implement the PSM Standard.  To ensure the PSM Standard if fully implemented, Schoep's Management will help plan the PSM compliance audits and track progress on recommendations as needed.  Schoep's Management will also promote the implementation of best practices to ensure employees have the necessary knowledge, skills, and tools.  
Additionally, Schoep's continues its refinement of an existing ammonia control system to increase the overall safety of the refrigeration system by augmenting the system's ability to monitor, report, and mitigate accid

employees in all parts of the process. Participation by employees can make significant contributions toward a safer workplace. Schoep's standard approach includes roles and responsibility matrices to clearly define expectations for all employees (including management).  All employees will, at a minimum, receive training on awareness and the PSM elements.
Specific procedures that are followed to define the employee participation at the Schoep's facility are contained in Element 1, Employee Participation.
Element 2-Process Safety Information (PSI): The purpose of compiling written process safety information is to provide a resource for the process hazard analysis team and other employees involved with process safety by providing data concerning the potential hazards posed by the process. Process Safety Information includes the following information:¿Hazards of the chemicals used in the process ¿Process technology information (e.g., simplified process flow diagram, process chemistry, max. intended ammonia inventory, safe upper/lower operating limits, evaluation of the consequences of deviation) ¿Process equipment information (e.g., P&IDs, classifications, materials, safety relief design and design basis, ventilation system design, safety systems/devices, codes & standards)
The process safety information must be updated whenever changes are made, and current information made available to employees. Specific procedures that are followed to develop and maintain Schoep's process safety information are contained in Element 2, Process Safety Information.
Element 3- Process Hazard Analysis (PHA):  A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) is the heart of PSM. The PHA is a thorough, orderly, systematic approach for identifying, evaluating, and controlling potential hazards within a process involving hazardous chemicals such as ammonia.
The Schoep's PHA program includes:¿Addressing process hazards, previous incidents and near misses with catastrophic potential ¿All changes (MOCs, in

ental releases of ammonia.  It consists of an automated computer based system that monitors system pressures and conditions it is equipped with an automatic notification system to let facility staff know if the system parameters deviate from normal operating conditions on a 24/7 basis.  The system automatically controls Ammonia Detectors, Sirens, isolation Fire Doors, Ventilation systems, King Valves and a Purging/Scrubbing System to reduce the amount of ammonia vapor expelled from the facility in the event of a major release in the main engine room.    
Emergency Response Information:  
As a part of the PSM program this facility maintains an emergency action plan in order to improve responsiveness to an emergency and to improve the reliability of action taken to mitigate the incident.  The plan includes all information needed to respond to an emergency situation, as well as complete notification instruction for Local, State, and Federal emergency response agencies.  Local hazmat teams have been through a detailed tour of the facility and our procedures to ensure a rapid and complete response in the event of an emergency.  Employees are trained in ammonia awareness during new employee orientation and on an annual basis during employment.    
Five Year Accident History:  This facility has had 1 reportable release in the last five years.  The amount was at or about 100lbs.  No injuries or exposures resulted either on or off-site. 
Local and State emergency response planning:
Schoep's has engaged with local and state agencies to promote facility awareness and has hosted numerous training sessions with local fire companies, Hazmat response crews, and Local, county, and state emergency management officials.

Element 4 -Operating Procedures:  OSHA requires the development, implementation, and maintenance of clearly written, detailed procedures, and practices for the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration process during all operating phases. The operating procedures provide employees involved in the operation of the ammonia refrigeration process with the written information and precautions necessary to safely perform their tasks in a consistent manner. Written procedures are required for start-up, normal operation, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and start-up following a turnaround or emergency shutdown. The operating procedures are required to address operating limits, including the consequences of deviations, steps to correct and/or avoid deviations, and safety systems and their functions.  Operating procedures also address safety and health considerations regarding the process, including the properties and hazards of the chemicals used, the precautions necessary to prevent exposure, control measures to be taken if contact or exposure to the chemical occurs, and any special or unique hazards (such as high noise levels).  Safe work practices must be in place to provide for the control of hazards during operations including, but not limited to confined space entry, lockout/tagout, opening process equipment or piping, and contr

ol over entrance into facility by contractors, maintenance, laboratory, or other support personnel. Operating procedures must be updated annually or more frequently if necessary to reflect current operating practices including changes in technology, equipment and facility changes. Specific procedures that are followed  to develop and maintain written operating procedures are contained in Element 4, Operating Procedures.
Element 5 - Personnel Training and Performance:  All employees and contractors who operate an ammonia refrigeration system must understand the safety and health hazards of this refrigerant and the refrigeration system. Employees and contractors who actually operate the system must understand how to do so. The training guideline describes the process by which personnel should operate and supervise the ammonia refrigeration system may be trained and qualified.
Schoep's standard for training includes: ¿Initial Training ¿Refresher Training ¿Classroom Training ¿On-the-Job Training (OJT) ¿Training for Primary Operator ¿Training for Support Operator ¿ Training for Production Ammonia Authorized ¿Training for Maintenance Ammonia Authorized ¿Training for Engineers, Supervisors, and Managers ¿Documentation and record keeping requirements
Specific procedures that are followed to develop and maintain required training programs at Schoep's facilities are contained in Element 5, Training.
Element 6 - Contractor Training and Performance: The safety program for all contract employers must be evaluated by Schoep's. The intent of the contractor safety element is to require employers who use contractors to perform work in and around processes that involve highly hazardous chemicals to establish a screening process so that they hire and use contractors who accomplish the desired job tasks without compromising the safety and health of employees at a facility.
